body: 'COUNTDOWN TO 12!' Most parents wouldn't dream of taking their small children to Times Square for New Year's Eve. So a suburban museum is taking Times Square to the children. Its celebration, ''Countdown to 12!,'' actually counts down from 12 -- 12 noon, that is. The Long Island Children's Museum, which first offered this New York New Year's theme
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: IT wasn't easy for critics to choose the best cultural offerings of 2010. But whatever moments onstage still linger in our memory, Jay Gatsby himself would advise against dwelling too long on the year that was. Now is the time to look forward: what performances in 2011 will inspire, shock, cheer us, maybe even change our world? Critics, reporters
title: LOOKING AHEAD; Time to Turn the Page

body: On Thursday, the fourth day after the blizzard that inundated New York, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg toured the city and took his lumps. The mayor visited the four boroughs beyond Manhattan, delivering the message that every street had been plowed and every stranded car and bus would soon be pulled or pushed out of the mire. But this was hardly a
title: Bloomberg Is Criticized on Storm Response as He Tours the City Beyond Manhattan

body: Tyrone Garrett has been admitted to the hospital for manic depression more than a dozen times. ''I was in Brooklyn V.A., Manhattan V.A., Northport V.A., Kingsbridge V.A., Maimonides, Kings County, Bellevue, Woodhull,'' he recited. ''Is there any I'm missing?'' Mr. Garrett, 52, first exhibited signs of mania in 1983, while on active duty in the
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; From Mental Health Patient to Wellness Coach

body: As New York City struggled with huge snowdrifts left by a crippling blizzard the day before, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged on Tuesday that the cleanup had been slower than expected and the impact worse than had been apparent when the snow stopped falling. While major thoroughfares seemed at least passable, especially in Manhattan, streets
title: City Struggles As Storm Impact Chastens Mayor

body: Good evening, snow-globe city. You survived the great post-Christmas whiteout of 2010. You frolicked and/or shoveled. You made molasses-on-snow. Now, perhaps, you can relax. Unless you're trying to get home. The trains and buses and subways are still messed up. For specifics on your evening commute, see below. And while you wait, try the
title: CITY ROOM;What Happens When a Plow Gets Stuck

body: In the Bronx, hundreds of thousands of pounds of meat came to a standstill. On Broadway, one of the busiest times of the year was anything but, and near Wall Street, traders were taking over downtown hotels to make sure they would be at work when the bell rang. For many New Yorkers, the onslaught of snow was an inconvenience, if not a delight, but
title: Blizzards and Business Don't Mix, but a Little Planning Can Help

body: On last week's Metropolitan cover, Wendell Jamieson recalled Christmas while growing up in Park Slope, Brooklyn. We asked readers to share their own neighborhood-based memories of the holiday. Below, excerpts from our favorites. Going to Riviera Ravioli in the Bronx with my Nonna to stock up for Xmas Eve dinner, and then Christmas in Woodhaven with
title: READER COMMENTS; Remembrances of Christmases Past

body: Every Saturday and Sunday at 6 a.m., Aftabudeen Edun pulls his truck into an expansive parking lot in Ozone Park, Queens, and unloads tiny bottles of perfume and moisturizer, lip balm and deodorant, laying them out in neat rows on folding tables. For 16 years, Mr. Edun, a 46-year-old immigrant from Guyana who owns two cosmetic stores on Liberty
title: Vendors at Aqueduct Flea Market Seek New Home as Closing Nears

body: FOR residents of Rosedale, which cozies up against Nassau County about 15 miles from Midtown Manhattan, being far from the center of things has its advantages. Relatively speaking there aren't many people in this southeastern corner of New York: a population of just 30,000 dispersed across two square miles, some on streets that dead-end on marshes.
title: LIVING IN | ROSEDALE, QUEENS; A Little Land That the Subway Forgot

body: His body was bruised and bloated, his mind losing its sentience. And so amid the suffocating chaos of a tent hospital in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, that was hastily erected there in the wake of the earthquake in January, Junior Clermond began gradually to accept what seemed inevitable. ''I gave up,'' Mr. Clermond said recently through an interpreter.
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Trying to Move Forward From Under the Rubble

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Center for Jewish History Through May 1, ''Zero to 10: First Decades/New Centuries,'' an exhibition in celebration of the center's 10th anniversary, featuring rare and historic items: a letter by Thomas Jefferson denouncing anti-Semitism and advocating religious freedom; a handwritten draft of Emma Lazarus's poem ''The
title: Spare Times

body: WINTERFEST Rodgers and Hammerstein echoed the views of legions of children in finding paper packages worth singing about. But in New York at this time of year they're also favorite things for polar bears. And snow leopards. ''They get different kinds of good treats that we put inside wrapped boxes that they actually enjoy unwrapping and taking
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Dance Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater (Friday through Sunday, Tuesday through Thursday) A familiar and beloved repertory is augmented by several new and unusual pieces. Judith Jamison's ''Forgotten Time'' (Friday and Saturday night) depicts rituals of love and tribal rites of passage. Alvin
title: The Listings

body: A sampling of performances of Handel's ''Messiah'' and other oratorios in New York. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.) Friday ABYSSINIAN BAPTIST CHURCH, 132 Odell Clark Place, at West 138th Street, Harlem. Handel's ''Messiah,'' with choir and orchestra; Jeryl Cunningham-Fleming, soprano; Carolyn Sebron,
title: Hallelujahs Everywhere

body: A sampling of holiday celebrations, including dance and theater events, in New York. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.) Friday IRISH ARTS CENTER, 553 West 51st Street, Clinton. ''An Irish Christmas,'' with traditional and contemporary songs; performers include the fiddler Rhys Jones, the accordionist Billy
title: Seasonal Revels

body: In 2004, when Cynthia Turay was deciding what to call her beauty-supply shop in Mill Basin, Brooklyn, she wanted the name to reflect her bumpy journey. She settled on God's Time Beauty Supply. ''Before I got the store, it was very hard to make it,'' Ms. Turay, 50, said. She had two broken marriages behind her, she had just moved her five children
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Mortgage Aid Restores Family's Brooklyn Refuge

body: MY GREAT-GRANDMOTHER ANNA Arbeit was born in Brownsville, Brooklyn, in 1905. It was a rich area, she said. Pennsylvania Avenue was a doctors' row, and the doctor made house calls in a horse and buggy. Anna's parents came from Austria as teenagers, and their neighborhood was filled with Jews from all over Europe who spoke to each other in Yiddish.
title: One Borough, Five Generations

body: IN August, Debra Kayman bought her first home, a two-family on Ashford Street in Cypress Hills, in the East New York section of Brooklyn. She came to the United States from Trinidad and Tobago in 1985, living in East Flatbush with family until her move to Cypress Hills in 1988. There she rented a succession of apartments, including one on Arlington
title: LIVING IN | CYPRESS HILLS, BROOKLYN; Prices Practical; Cuisines Colorful

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Guggenheim Museum Sunday and Monday at 7:30 p.m., the Works & Process series presents ''Poetic Responses to War,'' with readings from the poets and veterans Brian Turner and Bruce Weigl. In another part of the program, Elizabeth Farnum, soprano, and Alan Feinberg, pianist, will perform the music of George Flynn.
title: Spare Times

body: The hangar on the edge of Floyd Bennett Field has the familiar, post-apocalyptic look of urban decay, with ''Danger Keep Out'' spray painted in red across one of the building's doors. Many of the door panels have disappeared; so has most of the hangar's roof. Inside, a forest of weeds has sprouted through the floor. Sections of guardrail lie on the
title: FLOYD BENNETT FIELD JOURNAL; On an Edge of Brooklyn, New Hopes for a Park in Neglect

body: WINTER'S EVE AT LINCOLN SQUARE In ''A Christmas Carol'' Scrooge's spiritual opposite was Fezziwig, his genial boss of long ago who knew when to put aside workaday concerns, throw open his doors and invite everyone to a grand party. Something similar will happen in New York on Monday evening, but the businesses offering the revelry will be places
title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN

body: Dance Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. - American Ballet Theater (Saturday) In its first Newark performances in more than a decade, the company offers three one-act ballets: ''Seven Sonatas'' (with music by Scartlatti), the newest work by the troupe's artist in residence, Alexei Ratmansky; ''Company B,'' Paul Taylor's
title: The Listings

body: Cyclists, don't be afraid of a little chill in the air, especially when dressed in your best houndstooth check coats and wool vests for the Big Apple Tweed Fall Ride on Sunday. The organizers have devised a ride that combines old English style with bicycling, to create what they call ''a unique and memorable social experience that pays homage to a
title: Weekend Miser

body: Minutes before the earthquake hit on Jan. 12, the twin sisters Marc-Lysa and Markisha Racine, 6, were having a hard time focusing on their homework. Crawling on her hands and knees, Markisha repeatedly nudged her head into her mother's side, pleading, ''Just let me sit underneath you.'' Marc-Lysa became very quiet. Deciding to break for dinner,
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; After Haitian Earthquake, a New Life in Brooklyn

body: THE first movie theater in New York City, the Regent, opened in a German section of Harlem in 1913, with a showing of ''Pandora's Box.'' The Regent, at 116th Street and Seventh Avenue, was designed by Thomas W. Lamb and had about 1,800 seats. Since the 1960s, it has been an evangelical church. The city is dotted with such old theaters -- many
title: Once Palaces, Now Chain Stores

body: I WAS the youngest of three and the only girl in a family in which football was king, so life itself was a contact sport. So it should be no surprise that I was drawn to kinder, gentler physical activities (and those that involved sparkly costumes). But when I asked to add figure skating to my list of weekly activities, my mother said no. She
title: URBAN ATHLETE; Taking a Dream for a Few Spins

body: Manden n'ko Radio was abuzz on a recent Wednesday night. Despite the hiss and crackle of cellphone static, the radio program - actually a massive, New York-based conference call for Guinean expatriates - draws hundreds of listeners. ''The number of Guineans abroad doesn't compare to the number in the country,'' one caller declared in French around
title: CITY ROOM; Before Historic Vote, Guinean Airwaves Are Alive in New York

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Morgan Library & Museum Tuesday at 6:30 p.m., a discussion with Ron Chernow, author of the George Washington biography ''Washington: A Life''; $15, $10 for members. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; 225
title: Spare Tijmes

body: For years, fans in Brooklyn have devoured films from Nigeria, paying $3 for bootlegged copies of the latest releases at utilitarian stores in the Flatbush neighborhood that distribute cellphones, calling cards and an evening's entertainment. The low-budget, pulp features on the shelves, with soap-opera story lines and names like ''Key of Life'' or
title: Pirated Films From Nigeria Are Seized In Brooklyn

body: 'HALLOWHOA!' When you watch a tour guide in ''Hallowhoa!'' strap on a backpack with a long hose and a pump attached, you can't help thinking of Dan Aykroyd and Bill Murray suiting up in ''Ghostbusters.'' But the equipment here is not designed to vacuum stray ghouls and blobs of ectoplasm; it's to spray them silly. ''Silly spray'' plays a key role
title: SPARE TIMES, For Children

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Merchant's House Museum For the next two Fridays and Saturdays and this Thursday, from 6 to 10 p.m., candlelight tours of the house; $25, $13 for members. This Sunday, 3 to 5 p.m., ''From Parlor to Grave: 1865 Funeral Re-enactment,'' a staging of the funeral of Seabury Tredwell, the owner of the house in the mid-1800s,
title: Spare Times

body: Jimmy McMillan, running for governor as the candidate of the one-man Rent Is Too Damn High Party, stole the show at the debate on Monday night with his repeated and crystal-clear message: The. Rent. Is. Too. Damn. High. But how high, exactly, is too damn high for Mr. McMillan? That is a little harder to say. Mr. McMillan said in an interview on
title: A Foe of High Rent Is Vague About His Own

body: 'MEET THE BREEDS' It's part ''Project Runway,'' part ''American Idol'' and part ''MTV Cribs.'' But it's all cats and dogs. That's ''Meet the Breeds,'' which returns to Manhattan this weekend for its second year as a showcase for the animals that occupy so many American homes (and hearts). Sponsored by the American Kennel Club and the Cat Fanciers'
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: EVERYONE knows that the Comic-Con International in San Diego is like a nerds-are-cool Woodstock, where freak flags are waved proudly and Hollywood sweats to build buzz for its releases. But New York is the birthplace of comic books, and the New York Comic Con, at just five years old, has become a respectable contender as the ''it'' place for a
title: Graphic Evidence Of Comics Fanatics

body: For Children 'Angelina Ballerina the Musical' (Friday through Monday) That winsome white mouse who does all her scurrying in toeshoes is ready to pirouette onto the stage in this musical adaptation from Vital Theater Company. Based on the books by Katharine Holabird and Helen Craig and the PBS series ''Angelina Ballerina the Next Steps,'' the show
title: Spare Times

body: RUSSELL--Lillian on October 3, 2010. Life member of Hadassah. Retire administrative assistant at Humes-Schmidlapp, Associates, New York, New York. Loving wife of the late Eugene for 60 years. Devoted mother of Dr. Eric J. Russell (Dr. Sandra K. Fernbach) and the late Ronnye. Cherished grandmother of Meredith and Gabrielle (Abby). Also, cherished by
title: Paid Notice: Deaths RUSSELL, LILLIAN ON OCTOBER 3

author: Joshua Prager is the author of ''The Echoing Green: The Untold Story of Bobby Thomson, Ralph Branca and the Shot Heard Round the World.''
body: From his home run on Oct. 3, 1951, to his death on Aug. 16 at age 86, Bobby Thomson lived 21,502 days and, in that time, heard as many stories of where people were when he won the National League pennant for the New York Giants against the Brooklyn Dodgers at the Polo Grounds. He enjoyed them. He came to know through them that he had struck at just
title: BOX SEATS; The Shot That Carried All the Way to the Pyrenees

body: THE MEDIEVAL FESTIVAL New York City has had South American parrots roost in its electrical wiring, and coyotes and at least one caiman wander its parks. But once a year it provides a busy refuge for creatures far more fantastical than these: dragons and unicorns. Their sanctuary is Washington Heights, where the annual Medieval Festival will unfold
title: SPARE TIMES; For Children

body: Market Designs on View An exhibition of the designs for a new marketplace for the food vendors in Red Hook, Brooklyn, is on display at the Queens Museum of Art in Flushing Meadow through Sunday from noon to 6 p.m. Wednesdays through Sundays. Admission is by donation. Taco Series Andrew Carmellini of Locanda Verde has turned his talent to Mexico and
title: Calendar

body: ROTH--David. On September 25, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Loving father of Amy, Eric and Susan; father-in-law of Diana, Anne and Charles. Cherished grandfather of Aaron, Nathaniel, Isla and Indira. Devoted brother of Anna and the late Daniel. Former Executive Director of Jewish Child Care Association; Officer of National
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ROTH, DAVID

body: 'THE MAGIC ORANGE TREE' CELEBRATION When Diane Wolkstein listened to news reports after the January earthquake in Haiti, she continually heard references to that country's extreme poverty. She found the descriptions heartbreaking, she said, because in her view Haiti has at least one source of great wealth. ''It's not poor in culture,'' said Ms.
title: Spare Times: For Children

title: Paid Notice: Deaths SCHNITZLER, DR

Yummy Park Slope A free sampling from a variety of restaurants, food vendors and wine merchants in Park Slope, Brooklyn, will be held mostly along
title: Calendar

body: It is afternoon in Brooklyn, and school has just let out. Swarms of teenagers crowd the sidewalks, looking for a place to socialize. But near Downtown Brooklyn, at the entrances to the Atlantic Terminal mall, there is no hanging out at one popular meeting spot. Students are met by security guards, who block their path, ask questions and check IDs.
title: Policy at Brooklyn Mall Limits Entry by Young Groups

body: BROOKLYN BOOK FESTIVAL Animals, aliens, monsters, body parts (especially the posterior) and anything that's a gross-out -- these literary themes always seem to captivate children. The Brooklyn Book Festival offers them all, but its organizers also provide something for young people that many book fairs don't: titles and topics for those older than
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: If you're reading this, there's a good chance you're overworked and underpaid. But don't let it get you down. Instead get some perspective from the trials and tribulations of the 19th-century factory workers of the Lower East Side. In what was once a tenement built in 1863, theLower East Side Tenement Museumoffers a series of free lectures,
title: WEEKEND MISER; At Lower East Side Tenement Museum, Lectures and Opera

body: ''Day Long Throng Inspects New Tube,'' trumpeted the headline in The New York Times. It was exactly 100 years ago, and Long Islanders could now travel to Manhattan by rail. Their destination, at the end of the newly opened tunnel beneath the East River: the steel-and-marble transportation palace known as Pennsylvania Station, at the time the most
title: CITY ROOM; When The L.I.R.R. Reached Manhattan

body: The sun rose over the tireless Haitian rara musicians and the throng of ecstatic fans who followed them. A shimmying mother pushed a stroller. A man on roller skates danced into his seventh hour. Two police officers sipped coffee. The fans chanted, ''The day is coming.'' Shades rolled up on the windows they passed, revealing curious, sleepy
title: Energy of Haitian Sound Pulses After a Difficult Year

body: On Thursday night in Brooklyn, a suspect was chased and quickly surrounded by a group of patrolmen in blue uniform jackets who ordered him to halt. The man, David Flores, 33, who witnesses say was fondling himself in front of children in a Hasidic section of Brooklyn known as Borough Park, was about to be caught by the men in blue. He began
title: In Protecting Hasidic Neighborhoods, Squads Patrol Without Guns or Badges

body: FOR some families the summer game is baseball, for others basketball. For mine, it's miniature golf. For as long as I can remember, my 13-year-old son, Asher, and I have returned every season to Rye Playland or Saxon Woods in Westchester County. This year I floated a new idea. Would he want to putt our way across the city? Play mini-golf in each of
title: A Miniature-Golf Odyssey (Obstacles Included)

body: Sometimes, it takes a village to have fun, or at least a community center. The Stuyvesant High School community center in TriBeCa is helping by opening its doors to the public. Take the family swimming in the 75-foot-by-45-foot pool from 3 to 6 p.m. weekdays and 10 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. weekends, through August. Be sure to bring a swimsuit and cap,
title: Weekend Miser

body: THERE doesn't seem to be anything special about the wood-framed photographs of Flatbush Avenue from 1946 hanging on the walls of Lenny & John's Pizza, or the floor-to-ceiling stack of pizza boxes. The clear plastic containers of garlic, red pepper and oregano look the same as the ones at the pizzeria down the street, or across town. A slice costs
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | FLATLANDS; Look Around. That's Loyalty.

title: POSTING; Remaking the Face Of Brooklyn

body: Brooklyn and Queens are on the same island, which means Wally Backman can feel the tremors from out east. The Mets, his old team, are having a stinker of a season -- another stinker, that is to say -- but Backman's current team, the Cyclones, is winning two-thirds of its games. Backman knows how things work in New York, the back-page frenzy, Bring
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Backman Is Poised On Top Step of the Dugout

body: Pop Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. Arcade Fire (Wednesday and Thursday) Once an indie-rock darling, Arcade Fire has graduated to playing consecutive nights at Madison Square Garden -- not bad for a serious, often political band with a glockenspiel, French horn and hurdy-gurdy strapped inside its tour bus. The group's big,
title: The Listings

body: With the sun pounding down on Church Avenue in central Brooklyn, Johanna Washington dipped her fingers into an ice-cold cooler and shook her head as a man in a blue T-shirt approached, water bottles in hand. He and his dripping shopping cart marked the fourth competitor to set up shop at her intersection on Thursday afternoon, and she was not
title: THE CRUELEST MONTH?; Water Vendors Profit From the Heat

body: A man wearing sunglasses, for once unneeded, checked a pay phone for loose change and swept across Flatbush Avenue, a cup of hot coffee in his hand, the only figure moving on that slumbering colossus of commerce at 5 a.m. on Tuesday. Glowing green lights signaled no one to go, and the Brooklyn thoroughfare, usually a riot of bus exhaust, livery
title: THE CRUELEST MONTH; In a Sweltering City, It's Coolest Before Dawn

body: KIMBERLEE AULETTA grew up in Midtown, and for a long time Manhattan was where she imagined she would stay. Despite family roots in Brooklyn, where her father had grown up, she had never really considered moving there. But time brought a few epiphanies. The first came in a late 1990s winter, when friends who had moved to Brooklyn invited her to a
title: LIVING IN; History All Around, and Greenery Next Door

body: He was called the Jewish Caruso. Indeed, fervent enthusiasts sometimes referred to Caruso as the Italian Yossele Rosenblatt. Mr. Rosenblatt, who died in 1933, was regarded as the greatest cantor of his time. But his was a time when music was recorded on heavy shellac or celluloid 78 r.p.m. records. The quality of those recordings was never that
title: Bit by Electronic Bit, a Great Cantor's Voice Is Restored

body: IN a musty coffee shop in the suburbs of Portland, Ore., a dozen people occupying scruffy couches peer into laptop computers, their screens casting a blue glow across pasty faces. They scroll through online job listings, availing themselves of free Wi-Fi, as they pass another drizzly afternoon in the temporary office of the age. You run across this
title: The Great Rupture

body: DAN ZANES JAM & JUBILEE Dan Zanes plays regularly before crowds of enthusiastic young fans, but don't think of calling such events concerts. ''It will be more like an afternoon party,'' he said of the Dan Zanes Jam & Jubilee he has planned for the Fourth of July. ''More like a family reunion.'' (Many children would no doubt be delighted to trade in
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: IN a city that's ever on the go, it's a happy circumstance that there are so many decent sandwich shops. If inclined to, you can eat your meals three times a day between slices of bread, and in that manner dine lavishly. It's not just the same old sandwich suspects, either. Take breakfast, for instance, at the Prospect Lefferts Garden location of
title: $25 AND UNDER; Half a Loaf Is Better When Stuffed

body: Every so often, Aalim Moody, 5, and his twin sister, Aalima, break into a kind of secret code, chatting in a language their father does not understand. Walking along Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, they make out the lettering on kosher food shops and yeshiva buses, showing off all they learn at the Hebrew Language Academy Charter School in Midwood,
title: Success and Scrutiny at Hebrew Charter School

body: The World Cup's funny ball was still performing the dipsy-doodle on Sunday. Red cards were flying all over South Africa, and cheers in diverse languages were flying all over New York. While waiting to fly to South Africa next Sunday, I did the next best thing: I went to three matches in three very different neighborhoods, joining Slovene fans
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Sampling the Flavors of the City's Cup

body: CENTENNIAL BEE-DAY PARTY In Kafka's ''Metamorphosis'' Gregor Samsa awakens to discover that he has become an enormous cockroach. While that may be among the most unwelcome transformations on record, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will offer one on Saturday that's shorter, sweeter and sunnier: children changing themselves into bees. body: Any art lover can visit a museum, but the more adventurous can take to the streets for the New York City Department of Transportation's free bike tour on Saturday. From 9:30 a.m. to noon, a guide will lead cyclists across Manhattan to murals, sculptures and mosaics sponsored by the Urban Art Program, an effort to invigorate the city's streetscapes.

body: WEINTRAUB--Abraham, 100 years, died June 8, 2010. Our father Abraham was born in Brooklyn in 1920 and lived all his life in that borough. He was married for 57 years to Ruth Donenfeld Weintraub (1915-1993), to whom he was passionately devoted. Abe held a variety of jobs during his lifetime, which included chipper and caulker at the Brooklyn Navy
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WEINTRAUB, ABRAHAM

body: Anthony Henry's commuter van rolled west along Merrick Boulevard in Queens, packed nearly to capacity with nine passengers. It was 6:50 on a Friday morning, and the path ahead of him was clear until suddenly it wasn't: A van with a wobbly left rear tire, illegally plying the same route, burst in from a side street and barely cleared a car parked at
title: Legal and Illegal Vans Fight It Out for Fares

body: WALGREENS recently bought Duane Reade, the New York drugstore chain, for $1.1 billion. A 7,100-store company with headquarters in Deerfield, Ill., Walgreens said it would not immediately wipe away the Duane Reade brand, but it is exploring a switch to common bookkeeping and prescription systems, as well as the closing of some of Duane Reade's 258
title: Little Chains That Could ... and Still Do

body: 'TIGERS THE EXHIBITION' The most common way of getting inside a tiger isn't much fun -- just ask the deer in Asia. title: NEW YORK WORLD; Times Square Terror

title: HANDLEBARS | BRAMMO ENERTIA AND ZERO S; Silent and Green, But Not Quite There

body: If there was one person who didn't need to wear a name tag at Edward R. title: CITY ROOM; Remembering a Principal Who Embodied a School

body: For the past six years, Daniel Goldstein has been at the center of just about every rally, house party, concert and lawsuit opposed to the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn. title: For $3 Million, A Project's Foe Ends His Fight

title: Paid Notice: Deaths PEARLMAN, HUBERT S.

title: She's the One Holding the Keys

title: The Dixie Walker She Knew

title: STREETSCAPES | FLATBUSH, BROOKLYN; Erasmus Hall And Its Offspring

body: A Brooklyn jury found three police officers not guilty on Monday of abusing a suspect in the Prospect Park subway station during a 2008 arrest, in a case that recalled some of the city's most notorious police brutality episodes but never generated as much public outcry or departmental change. title: All Officers Are Acquitted in Police Abuse Trial

title: At a Neglected Movie Palace, Cobwebs Are Given Notice

title: A Prewar Home, To Say the Least

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Moving Beyond a Childhood Beset by Loss and Illness
